text: SotN was good, because of its sound track and because it was radically different from all (at the time) other games in the series. I grew up with Super Castlevania IV, so it will always be my favourite. It had the best version of Vampire Killer I've heard, and excellent versions of The Beginning and Bloody Tears. My favourite original songs were Simon's Theme, the treasure room music, and Room of close Associates.

author: HikariLicht

text:
"everyone thinks that SotN is the best.
everyone."

LMFAO!

*Sarcastically* Ha ha.... Like that's saying much.
author: Jonathan Goldberg

text:
xtrife57 I agree, it's a matter of opinion. The best performance between games is opinion.

Society as a whole is the one who dictates which game is the best.

And within society, it is the single opinion of the majority which dictates a game to be considered better over another.

But what's funny is that the word "best" is completely taken out of context because they unwillingly mean "most revered", not "best"....

"Best game" and "most revered game".... Two completely different things.
author: Jonathan Goldberg

text:
You're just saying what's true? NitM/SotN is the best Castlevania game and it probably always will be?....

Those comments you made right there.... They are just absolutely THE biggest pieces of hogwash I ever heard concerning Castlevania.... An act of true ignorance at its finest.

Where the hell do you get off declaring what's true and what's not false? What you just said weren't even opinions. You are declaring it as fact, just by blatantly stating what is truth worthy.
author: Jonathan Goldberg

text:
"Easy or not , it's the best in the series"

No it's not. NitM/SotN is not the perfect game you believe it to be.

Despite the game greatness, it's got way too many problems.

To believe that NitM/SotN was a perfect Castlevania game is an act of ignorance.
author: Jonathan Goldberg

text:
i liked lament of innocense better than COD

text: I am a big fan of Castlevania series SOTN and CoD are great games. I can't say which is the best.

text:
everyone thinks that SotN is the best.

author: Atma505

text: well basically, players are the ones who make a game be "good". A great game is a game that a lot of people think is good, otherwise it probably sucks, but thats not true. The truth is that if you enjoy a game more than another, if you find it more interesting then what more reason do you need to say its better. Its all a matter of opinion, really, but JonathanFerGold's comment is definitely not dumb.
author: Alucard Tepes

text:
I wouldn't say it's dumb.

In my opinion, I think SOTN is better, but it's hard to tell since it's the 1st Castlevania game I've played.

Portrait of Ruin, despite what people think, is also an awesome game.

It's very hard to tell which one is the best, but it's definitely among those three.
author: Diego Vizia

text:
You probably didn't even give Curse of Darkness a chance....

The game is so much better than what people make it out to be.
author: Jonathan Goldberg

text:
Who says that? People that obviously aren't you?

Stop letting other people make decisions for you about games.

Make your own goddamn decisions.
author: Jonathan Goldberg

text:
No doubt, no doubt....

I can't wait either. Honestly, I love all the Castlevania games. It's just that Curse of Darkness is so unique from them all. Like I was saying before, it is a refleshing experience from all the other Castlevanias.

I don't know.... Unlike most people, I found very little things wrong with the game. Well as minor as it is, I can say that Leon Belmont's walking/running animations has Hector's walking/running animations beat by a thousand paces.
author: Jonathan Goldberg

text:
"Hahahaah , fool ...

everyone and everything knows that Symphony of the night is the best Castlevania game ever"

LMFAO! Who the fuck is everyone and everything?
author: Jonathan Goldberg

text:
Indeed.

Many Castlevania fans don't like this game because they can't accept the transition from 2D to 3D, even though CoD is exactly what a Castlevania game should look like in 3D.

In addition, the vast majority of gamers don't stop to take a look at details on the scenarios or keep playing the game after beating it looking for secret areas. Many don't even listen to the music!

I don't think fans will ever accept a 3D Castlevania, but I can't wait for a next-gen Castlevania to come out.
author: Diego Vizia

text:
"The evolution of the ID's, the item stealing for crafting rare weapons, the secret rooms, the chairs, the beautiful scenarios, the wonderful music..."

That comment pretty much sums up when I love this Castlevania. And because the majority of the Castlevania fans put this game down despite those reasons, I know that this game is terribly underrated.
author: Jonathan Goldberg

text:
Ha ha ha, that's crazy dude.

Well I have to admit: When I first played this game, I absolutely hated the first 20 minutes (The Abandoned Castle, basically). However once I arrived at Baljhet Mountains and started fighting monster left and right, weapon crafting and leveling up.... I was like "This game is incredible!". I had realized the experience was deep and refreshing from typical 2-D Castlevania games. And that was me when the game first came out in 2005.
author: Jonathan Goldberg

text:
No need for apology: It was your opinion. I am just known to challenge people's opinions, when I realize they don't understand what's really presented. It was never personal.

Yeah I agree: While Curse of Darkness may have minor restrictions on exploration, the visual environments themselves are too beautiful not to be desired. But then again, this isn't Grand Theft Auto or Shadows of the Colossus. Honestly, I never had the intention of playing a Castlevania game for the sake of exploration.
author: Jonathan Goldberg

text:
I don't know the reason. I myself can't understand why I didn't enjoy the game the first time.

The evolution of the ID's, the item stealing for crafting rare weapons, the secret rooms, the chairs, the beautiful scenarios, the wonderful music... how come I only appreciate the music the first time? ... I don't have an answer for that...

All I can say now is that I'm sorry for the way I treated you, and that you were right this whole time. I can be a pain sometimes...
author: Diego Vizia

text:
Say what?

I'm confused... Are you serious?

Then, I'm just confused as to why your previous comments were negative about the game?

Can you clarify as to why you originally thought this game sucked? I was always under the impression that the whole "Curse of Darkness" experience was impossible to misunderstand, considering the awesome shit you do in the game.
author: Jonathan Goldberg

text:
Yes, there's a bit of exploration restriction and a couple of musics that I personally don't like, as well as a mediocre last level. But those are minor flaws. The game has SO MANY good things that you just forget about them.

I just can't understand why I didn't appreciate it right from the start.

I feel the obligation to apologize to JonathanFerGold, and I have to agree with him: Castlevania Curse of Darkness is the Ultimate Castlevania Experience.
author: Diego Vizia

text:
When you talk about something, only to later realize you were wrong, the correct thing to do is to face your past words and accept you commited an error.

And here, I am the one who was wrong. CoD is one of the best games, and it doesn't deserve my previous comments.

I know I may sound stupid, but I replayed it a few weeks ago, and the experience was indescribable. The scenarios, the music, the Innocent Devils, the weapon crafting... everything was amazing.
author: Diego Vizia

text:
Thank you xtrife57!

God, someone finally agrees with me in regards to such an great Castlevania game. I can't understand why it's so fucking underrated?
author: Jonathan Goldberg

text:
DiegoVizia, nobody here is saying that graphics make a game better.

All I was saying was that NitM/SotN was way too easy. It should have been harder, like Minuet of Dawn/AoS and Crucifix of the Blue Moon/DoS.
author: Jonathan Goldberg

text: As great as Nocturne in the Moonlight/Symphony of the Night is, the game is way too easy!
author: Jonathan Goldberg

text: Yeah, I think this Curse of Darkness game was great. I hate it when people block their minds and say that any 3d castlevania simpy sucks/will suck.

text: This VGM is really good.

author: Immoral Flame

text: Ms Yamane is Awesome!
author: Venom Neff

text: I gotta give this game back to my pal soon...I'm gonna miss it :(
author: Sephiko

text:
Who cares about graphics or difficulty?

The important things are: Gameplay, story and music.

The gameplay of CoD sucks! You can't interact with anything and you can't even fall off a platform because there are "invisible walls" everywhere. The story is so empty I can't even remember it. The music is excellent, but that's the only good thing in the game.

So go then and play Gears of War if you enjoy good graphics and leave Castlevania for good gamers.
author: Diego Vizia

text:
You're totally crazy. I'm one of the biggest fans of Castlevania, but I have to admit this game is bad.

Level designs lack inspiration. You always feel like you're inside 4 walls, even if you're in the forest. And that's because the trees and all objects in the world are not designed with polygons. Everything is just a wall with a texture making it look like there's a vase, a candle, or a window. But all there is is a wall with a texture, so you can't interact with the objects you see.
author: Diego Vizia

text:
Why would expect anyone to hate you for saying that? If I had a choice, I would own this game over NitM/SotN.

I love NitM/SotN, but it has problems (Such as the lack of a boss rush mode along with a single difficulty level that is so, so far from being a true "break a sweat" experience).
author: Jonathan Goldberg

text:
Yes! It would!

: )
author: Jonathan Goldberg

text:
I got nega-rated up the ass for saying that CoD was better than NitM/SotN? I played both games religiously and I came to learn that CoD was just a better, longer and harder game. SotN was too easy. And graphics have no impact on this matter either.

"everyone and everything knows that Symphony of the night is the best Castlevania game ever"? LMFAO! What a shallow remark.... I'm not even gonna dignify that with a response.

: )
author: Jonathan Goldberg

text:
Nice music =D
Would it be blasphemous to say that I have yet to play a single Castlevania game? D;

I can't decide which one is better. But the 3 I have listed are the select few best Castlevania songs in history.

With time, Michiru Yamane seems to be getting better and better.... Like a fine aged wine.
